title: Agnatius Paasi
text:
Agnatius Paasi (born 30 November 1991) is a Tongan professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who plays as a and for <a href="St%20Helens%20RLFC">St Helens</a> in the <a href="Betfred%20Super%20League">Betfred Super League</a> and <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> at international level.
He previously played for the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> in two separate spells, and also the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast Titans</a> in the <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a>.
Background.
Paasi was born in <a href="Lapaha%2C%20Tonga">Lapaha, Tonga</a>, and moved to <a href="Auckland%2C%20New%20Zealand">Auckland, New Zealand</a> when he was three years old.
Paasi played his junior football for <a href="Mangere%20East%20Hawks">Mangere East Hawks</a>. At age 17, Paasi moved to Australia on a <a href="scholarship">scholarship</a> to play for <a href="Keebra%20Park%20State%20High%20School">Keebra Park State High School</a> where they won the <a href="GIO%20Schoolboy%20Cup">Arrive Alive Cup</a> in 2009. He also played some <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">Australian rules football</a> for the school. He was offered a contract with the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a> under 20's, but complications with his visa saw him return to New Zealand, where he again played for the <a href="Mangere%20East%20Hawks">Mangere East Hawks</a> before being signed by the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a>.
Playing career.
Early career.
In 2011, Paasi played for the Warriors <a href="National%20Youth%20Competition%20%28rugby%20league%29">Toyota Cup</a> Under-20s team. On 5 October 2011, Paasi played in the Warriors' <a href="2011%20NRL%20Under-20s%20season%23Finals%20Series">2011 NYC</a> Grand Final victory over the <a href="North%20Queensland%20Cowboys">North Queensland Cowboys</a>, playing off the interchange bench in the Warriors' 31-30 golden point extra time victory. On 6 October 2011, Paasi was named 18th man for the <a href="Junior%20Kiwis">Junior Kiwis</a>. 
In 2012, Paasi moved on to the Warriors <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Cup">New South Wales Cup</a> team, the <a href="Auckland%20Vulcans">Auckland Vulcans</a>, and he also played for the Vulcans in 2013. At the start of 2014 Paasi wasn't contracted to any NRL team but was given a chance to play in the Warriors pre-season games, earning a contract with the Warriors <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Cup">NSW Cup</a> side.
2014.
After a few impressive performances in the NSW Cup, Paasi was handed his <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">NRL</a> debut for the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> in Round 19 against the <a href="Brisbane%20Broncos">Brisbane Broncos</a>, where he played off the interchange bench in the Warriors 28-22 loss at <a href="Suncorp%20Stadium">Suncorp Stadium</a>. 
This was Paasi’s only first grade match in the 2014 season. He was named as the Warriors NSW Cup Player of the Year. In November, Paasi signed a train and trial contract with the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Titans">Gold Coast Titans</a>, starting from 2015. On 16 October, Paasi played for <a href="Tonga%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Tonga</a> against <a href="Papua%20New%20Guinea%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Papua New Guinea</a>, starting at second-row in the 32-18 loss in <a href="Lae%2C%20Papua%20New%20Guinea">Lae</a>.
2015.
In Round 1, Paasi made his club debut for the Gold Coast Titans against the <a href="Wests%20Tigers">Wests Tigers</a>, playing off the interchange bench in the Titans 19-18 loss at <a href="Cbus%20Super%20Stadium">Cbus Super Stadium</a>. In Round 4 against the <a href="Cronulla-Sutherland%20Sharks">Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks</a>, he scored his first career try in the Titans 24-22 win at <a href="Remondis%20Stadium">Remondis Stadium</a>. Paasi’s good form in the Titans early matches earned him a 2-year contract extension with the Titans. He finished his impressive year with him playing in 18 matches and scoring 2 tries.
2016.
In February, Paasi was named in the Titans <a href="2016%20NRL%20Auckland%20Nines">2016 NRL Auckland Nines</a> squad, where he was named in the Team of the Tournament. He was described as, "undoubtedly the weekend’s biggest surprise packet" and perhaps the best player of the Nines. Paasi enjoyed a solid <a href="2016%20NRL%20season">2016 NRL season</a> with him playing in all the Titans 25 matches and scored 5 tries.
2017.
Paasi’s <a href="2017%20NRL%20season">2017 NRL season</a> was limited due to a shoulder injury, playing in 11 matches for the Titans. On 5 November 2017, Paasi was released from his final year of his contract with the Titans to join his former club the <a href="New%20Zealand%20Warriors">New Zealand Warriors</a> on a 2-year deal, starting from 2018.
2019.
In Round 24 2019, Paasi played his 100th NRL game in the Warriors 10-31 defeat by the <a href="South%20Sydney%20Rabbitohs">South Sydney Rabbitohs</a> at <a href="Mount%20Smart%20Stadium">Mt Smart Stadium</a> in Auckland.
2020.
On 13 November, it was announced that Paasi had signed for <a href="St%20Helens%20R.F.C.">St Helens</a> on a two-year deal starting in 2021.
2021.
In round 1 of the 2021 Super League season, he made his debut for St. Helens in their 29-6 victory over Salford. Paasi was knocked out in the second half of the game after a collision with Salford player <a href="Pauli%20Pauli">Pauli Pauli</a>. He was awarded Man of the Match on his Challenge Cup debut, spearheading his team's victory over Leeds.
On 17 July, he played for St. Helens in their 26-12 <a href="2021%20Challenge%20Cup%20Final">2021 Challenge Cup Final</a> victory over Castleford.
On 9 October, he played for St. Helens in their <a href="2021%20Super%20League%20Grand%20Final">2021 Super League Grand Final</a> victory over <a href="Catalans%20Dragons">Catalans Dragons</a>.
